G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who, by any act or omission, “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable to the aggrieved tenant for actual and statutory damages, including, in appropriate cases, multiple damages and reasonable attorney’s fees.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 2 and 19.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 2 and 19, the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department has subject-matter jurisdiction over this civil action because the amount in controversy is within the court’s jurisdictional limit and the cause of action arises under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge District Court because the rental property that is the subject of this dispute is located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 223, § 2; G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge District Court because the rental property that is the subject of this dispute is located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 223, § 2; G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 11\u201315.proposition: Additional Massachusetts statutes and decisions reinforce tenants’ rights to habitable and reasonably quiet premises, including: a. G.L. c. 186, §§ 11–15 (tenant protections and remedies); b. G.L. c. 239, § 2A (retaliatory evictions and tenant protections); c. Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) (landlord/owner duties regarding building conditions); d. Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing warranty of habitability, often applied together with quiet enjoyment principles).

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 2A.proposition: Additional Massachusetts statutes and decisions reinforce tenants’ rights to habitable and reasonably quiet premises, including: a. G.L. c. 186, §§ 11–15 (tenant protections and remedies); b. G.L. c. 239, § 2A (retaliatory evictions and tenant protections); c. Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) (landlord/owner duties regarding building conditions); d. Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing warranty of habitability, often applied together with quiet enjoyment principles).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord, by action or inaction, creates or permits conditions on the property that substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment, even if the landlord does not specifically intend the interference.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment where substantial interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, even without a specific intent to cause that interference. The court explicitly rejects an intent requirement, emphasizing that the landlord’s conduct and its foreseeable consequences, including permitting and failing to control the noisy lounge, are what matter. This aligns directly with the stated proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: In Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994), the Court reiterated that interference is “substantial” when it materially impairs the character and value of the tenancy, distinguishing such conditions from mere inconvenience or annoyance.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment in terms of “serious interference” and explains that such a breach occurs when acts or omissions “impair the character and value of the leasehold,” distinguishing this from lesser disturbances. Later, applying that standard, the court states that if tenants cannot use the common areas, this “constitutes a serious interference” and “substantially impairs the character of the leased premises,” which matches the proposition’s description of substantial interference as materially impairing the character and value of the tenancy and going beyond mere inconvenience or annoyance.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: In Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), the Court recognized that persistent, disruptive conditions (there, recurrent flooding and sewage problems) can give rise to liability for breach of quiet enjoyment and may support an award of damages for emotional distress.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The Court expressly treats the recurrent flooding and sewage as an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and explains that statutory “actual and consequential damages” include emotional distress resulting from those conditions. Although the separate $10,000 quiet‑enjoyment verdict was vacated as duplicative, the opinion squarely recognizes that persistent, unsanitary, disruptive conditions can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment and that emotional distress damages are a permissible component of recovery for that interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises…. The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case, not only were Solomon’s injuries foreseeable, but the jury found specifically that Gem knew or should have known that if it permitted floods to occur, Solomon would suffer emotional harm. Therefore, Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14….”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Similarly, in cases such as Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005), and Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), Massachusetts appellate courts have held that landlords may be liable for failing to prevent or remedy serious interferences, including noise and conditions that disturb tenants’ use of their homes.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Jablonski holds that landlords may be liable for failing to prevent or remedy serious interferences (including noise/conditions disturbing tenants’ use). In this opinion, the Appeals Court reiterates the general quiet-enjoyment standard but ultimately finds no breach and expressly finds no interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment because the landlord promptly addressed the conditions. Thus, Jablonski does not itself stand as authority imposing liability; it actually affirms a defense verdict and rejects the tenant’s quiet-enjoyment claim.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850-851 (1997). … We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Similarly, in cases such as Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005), and Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), Massachusetts appellate courts have held that landlords may be liable for failing to prevent or remedy serious interferences, including noise and conditions that disturb tenants’ use of their homes.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not address landlord liability for noise or other disturbing conditions generally; it specifically concerns whether a statutory violation of the lead paint law automatically constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court holds that a landlord is liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 only upon at least negligent conduct with notice or reason to know of the condition, and explicitly rejects strict liability based solely on the lead paint statute. Thus, it does not stand for the broader proposition that landlords may be liable for failing to prevent or remedy serious interferences such as noise; it is about the fault standard and the non-automatic linkage between lead paint violations and quiet enjoyment claims.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to his actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs of the action and, in the discretion of the Court and as authorized by statute, reasonable attorney’s fees (even though Plaintiff is currently self-represented). See also, e.g., Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979) (discussing remedies under G.L. c. 186, § 14); Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982) (landlord liability under § 14).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The case clearly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 as providing a remedy of actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee, so it supports that portion of the proposition. However, Darmetko concerns fees awarded to legal services counsel and does not discuss whether a self‑represented (pro se) plaintiff can obtain attorney’s fees; it therefore cannot be cited as authority that a currently self‑represented plaintiff is entitled to such fees. The citation is accurate as to the structure of § 14 remedies, but overreaches as to pro se attorney’s fees.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … The payment of attorney’s fees is authorized explicitly by G. L. c. 186, § 14. An unsuccessful defendant is liable for ‘the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982).proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to his actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs of the action and, in the discretion of the Court and as authorized by statute, reasonable attorney’s fees (even though Plaintiff is currently self-represented). See also, e.g., Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979) (discussing remedies under G.L. c. 186, § 14); Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982) (landlord liability under § 14).
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982).support_reasoning: Wolfberg does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14, and confirms that the statute allows recovery of actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater. However, it does not discuss costs or attorney’s fees under § 14, and in fact expressly declines to address the attorney’s‑fees issue raised in the appeal. Thus, Wolfberg cannot be cited as authority that a plaintiff is entitled to attorney’s fees under § 14, whether represented by counsel or self‑represented.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982).relevant_excerpt:
“The judge awarded $990 (three months’ rent) to the tenants on a finding that the landlord had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. General Laws c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, allows tenants to recover ‘actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater,’ for violation of that statute…

…The tenants have neither briefed nor argued the issue of attorney’s fees. We therefore do not reach this issue.”

Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust.raw_text: Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018)
Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust.proposition: Additional Massachusetts statutes and decisions reinforce tenants’ rights to habitable and reasonably quiet premises, including: a. G.L. c. 186, §§ 11–15 (tenant protections and remedies); b. G.L. c. 239, § 2A (retaliatory evictions and tenant protections); c. Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) (landlord/owner duties regarding building conditions); d. Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing warranty of habitability, often applied together with quiet enjoyment principles).

Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1.proposition: Additional Massachusetts statutes and decisions reinforce tenants’ rights to habitable and reasonably quiet premises, including: a. G.L. c. 186, §§ 11–15 (tenant protections and remedies); b. G.L. c. 239, § 2A (retaliatory evictions and tenant protections); c. Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) (landlord/owner duties regarding building conditions); d. Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing warranty of habitability, often applied together with quiet enjoyment principles).
Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1.support_reasoning: This separate concurring/dissenting opinion in Hemingway (along with the majority, which it discusses and partially concurs in) is a foundational Massachusetts case recognizing an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and tying that obligation to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. The opinion expressly calls for abandoning the old caveat emptor rule for dwellings, makes the landlord’s obligation to provide habitable premises mutually interdependent with the tenant’s obligation to pay rent, and frames habitability in terms of statutory and code-based minimum standards—concepts that are frequently applied together with quiet enjoyment principles in later Massachusetts law.
Hemingway v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair ….’ … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”}
